conclusion: Analyze the motion of the charged ball under gravity and electric field.
Ball moves along a straight line at angle θ to the electric field direction.
Uniform electric field is horizontal; ball starts from point O with velocity v0.
Net force acting on the ball is directed along the line of motion.
Determine forces acting on the ball: gravity and electric force.
Gravity acts downward with magnitude mg.
Electric force acts opposite to electric field with magnitude qE.
Resolve forces into components parallel and perpendicular to the line of motion.
Parallel components: gravity mg sin θ, electric force qE cos θ.
Perpendicular components: gravity mg cos θ, electric force qE sin θ.
Net force must be directed along the line; perpendicular components cancel out.
Parallel components must be equal in magnitude but opposite in direction.
Equation: mg sin θ = qE cos θ.
Calculate work done by electric force: W_e = -qE Δx cos θ.
Ball moves against the electric field, so work done is negative.
Change in electric potential energy ΔU_e = -W_e = qE Δx cos θ.
Relate Δx to initial velocity v0 and angle θ using kinematic equations.
Ball moves along a straight line at angle θ to electric field.
Final answer: ΔU_e = qE Δx cos θ.
Expression gives difference in electric potential energy based on initial conditions.
Exact value of Δx requires additional information about initial velocity and time of flight.
